<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 312, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 429, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 517, 765, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 548, 359, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 787, 135]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 shows the apparatus after the weight has been lowered into the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 816, 165]]<|/det|>
Diagram 3 shows the apparatus after the weight and the cork have been submerged.

<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A pulse of sound is produced at the bottom of a boat. The sound travels through the water and is reflected from a shoal of fish. The sound reaches the boat again after 1.2 s. The speed of sound in the water is \(1500 \text{m / s}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 128, 635, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 586, 271]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 280, 170, 299]]<|/det|>

<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 280, 373, 299]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 280, 715, 299]]<|/det|>

<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 325, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
An observer stands at the finish line of a 100 m race. He wants to time the winner's run. He starts his stop-watch as soon as he sees the smoke from the starting gun instead of when he hears the bang.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 386, 395, 404]]<|/det|>
What is the reason for doing this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 134, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 414, 458, 432]]<|/det|>
Light travels much faster than sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 440, 131, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 440, 611, 459]]<|/det|>
There is a risk he might respond to an echo from a wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 467, 131, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 467, 512, 485]]<|/det|>
Humans react slower to sound than to light.

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 494, 561, 512]]<|/det|>
Humans react more quickly to sound than to light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 537, 549, 555]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 596, 475, 613]]<|/det|>
It is magnetic and strongly magnetised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 622, 131, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 622, 425, 640]]<|/det|>
It is magnetic and unmagnetised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 131, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 650, 512, 667]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 133, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 675, 462, 694]]<|/det|>
It is non-magnetic and unmagnetised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 304, 106, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 761, 322]]<|/det|> Which statement explains the meaning of the half-life of a radioactive isotope? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 332, 134, 351]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 332, 631, 350]]<|/det|> half the time taken for one nucleus of the isotope to decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 359, 133, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 599, 377]]<|/det|> half the time taken for the isotope to decay completely <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 131, 403]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 384, 631, 403]]<|/det|> the time taken for half of the nuclei of the isotope to decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 411, 133, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 411, 635, 428]]<|/det|> the time taken for one nucleus of the isotope to split in half <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 456, 106, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 720, 473]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a lead-lined box used for storing radioactive sources. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 483, 603, 616]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 480, 648]]<|/det|> Why is the inside of the box lined with lead? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 658, 133, 676]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 658, 559, 676]]<|/det|> It helps the sources to stay radioactive for longer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 685, 133, 702]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 685, 361, 702]]<|/det|> It makes the box heavier. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 711, 133, 728]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 711, 529, 728]]<|/det|> It makes the radioactive sources more stable. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 738, 133, 755]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 738, 680, 755]]<|/det|> It reduces the amount of radiation that can escape from the box. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 839, 920, 871]]<|/det|> Permission to reproduce items where third-party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible. Every reasonable effort has been made by the publisher (UCLES) to trace copyright holders, but if any items requiring clearance have unwittingly been included, the publisher will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 878, 920, 910]]<|/det|> To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer-related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge Assessment International Education Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet.
